Name: main
Comment: Lexically conditioned split-S in the second person only (src:koehn1986apalai[109]).

Name: non-past continuative
Comment: src:koehn1986apalai[100], -Ṽko and -torɨ̃ko (mana), somewhere between finite and non-finite? person marking: sometimes takes second person marking, but usually occurs with a copula and is consequently zero-marked

Name: supine
Comment: src:koehn1986apalai[77--78], takes set II markers in transitive verbs, probably complementary distribution

Name: past continuative
Comment: suffix -se, unknown marking, only V-initial verbs?

Name: past completive
Comment: src:koehn1986apalai[100], t-X-se, very frequent

Name: gnomic
Comment: Innovated construction.

Name: main
Comment: Lexically conditioned split-S.

Name: past habitual
Comment:
Person marking is identical to the cons:kar_main, except for third person, where morph:kar_3i and obj:t(ɨ)- are found.
morph:kar_3i occurs as a 3>3 marker, obj:t(ɨ)- occurs with intransitive verbs and can be used with transitive verbs to express a passive meaning: ex:kar-45

Name: nominalized
Comment: src:hoff1968carib[133--157]

Name: main
Comment: Lexically conditioned split-S in the second person only (src:hixkaryanaderby1985[188--189]).

Name: nominalized
Comment: src:hixkaryanaderby1985[230--234]

Name: main
Comment: Lexically conditioned split-S.

Name: inherited
Comment: This construction can also be used with innovated 1>2 and 1>3 forms, see cons:ing_old1

Name: inherited new
Comment: This is an innovative Set I construction; it differs from cons:ing_old by its 1>2 and 1>3 forms.

Name: imperative
Comment: This is the inherited imperative construction; there is also another (src:cruz2005fonologia[285ff]).

Name: remote past
Comment: Differs from cons:kax_main in allowing a third person prefix morph:kax_3i.

Name: progressive
Comment: An innovative progressive construction with obj:-rɨ (INTR), obj:-roko (TR).

Name: imperative
Comment: There is also another, innovated imperative construction. It is unclear whether the obj:a- occurring in intransitive imperatives is morph:mac_2s or morph:mac_2p (although it’s likely the latter).

Name: new imperative
Comment: Polite / futute imperative forms innovated from earlier declarative constructions.

Name: main
Comment: Lexically conditioned split-S, except that the reflexes of cogset:12a have been merged completely with reflexes of cogset:12 (src:maquiritaricaceres2011[181]).

Name: imperative
Comment:
Only Sp verbs take second person prefixes (src:maquiritaricaceres2011[130]).

While src:maquiritaricaceres2011[229] claims that third person P is marked with obj:i- (or palatalization), there are no examples of transitive imperatives with obj:i-.
I have found one counterexample, where one would expect the verb root to have the form obj:ʃarrə (underlyingly obj:i-sarrə):
ex:mak-10

Name: mixed
Comment:
This is an innovative construction, derived from the cons:ara_old, with the exception of third person markers.
Lexically conditioned split-S.
In the first person Sa marking, there is another, also lexically conditioned, split, wherein a reflex of cogset:12 is replacing that of cogset:1sa (src:alves2017arara[149]).

Name: intermediate past
Comment:
Person marking is identical to the cons:ara_main, except for third person, where morph:ara_3int is found. Notably, this marker cannot co-occur with the TAM marker obj:-te, which does occur with the other person prefixes (src:alves2017arara[155]).
Although the description indicates that all third person scenarios are marked with obj:mon(i)-, it seems like Sp verbs do not receive the marker.
There is only one example of an Sp verb in the intermediate past with a third person argument, and it shows the idiosyncratic marker obj:ju-: ex:ara-43
All other examples of intransitive verbs with third person arguments in the intermediate past are with Sa verbs.

Name: remote past
Comment:
Person marking is identical to the cons:ara_main, except for third person, where morph:ara_3rem is found. Notably, this marker cannot co-occur with the TAM marker obj:-ne, which does occur with the other person prefixes (src:alves2017arara[154]).
There are no examples of Sp verbs in the remote past, and, similarly to the cons:ara_int, it is unclear whether they would take morph:ara_3rem or the Sp marker morph:ara_3i.

Name: innovated
Comment: Innovated construction, occurs with PST -pə, PRS Ø, FUT -se,

Name: inherited
Comment: This is what remains of the Set I construction. As in other Pemongan languages, it is functionally restricted, in lg:pemon it prominently occurs in questions (and answers to these questions). Local and inverse scenarios rarely occur, mostly direct and third person scenarios are found. Forms with cogset:12 now have a prohibitive meaning, as in lg:macushi. I have not found any examples for 2>1 scenarios, and only one uncertain example for 1>2. 1S is zero-marked (remnants of rc:u- are present), so one would expect 2>1 to be, too.

Name: main
Comment: Lexically conditioned split-S.

Name: past-perfective
Comment: This is the lg:trio past-perfective clause. It only differs from other main clauses in that cogset:3ky was added to third person forms.

Name: habitual past
Comment: V-initial Sp verbs show a generic morph:tri_3i, Sa verbs don't. Suffix: -se and allomorphs src:triomeira1999[329--332]

Name: supine
Comment: V-initial Sp verbs show a generic morph:tri_3i, Sa verbs don't. Suffix: -se and allomorphs src:triomeira1999[329--332]

Name: remote past
Comment: t-X-se, src:triomeira1999[333--335]

Name: negative
Comment: src:triomeira1999[335--337], Set II but with 3P.NEG in-, suffix -sewa

Name: adverbial
Comment: posteriority -tuuwə, cause -təkərə,  src:triomeira1999[337--339]. Seti II, with cogset:wnmlz.

Name: main
Comment:
Lexically conditioned split-S; but sparse data.
The Sp markers morph:wmr_1p and morph:wmr_2p have only been found with the verbs obj:kɨta ‘to shout’ and obj:jwapo ‘to dance’, respectively.

Name: main
Comment: Lexically conditioned split-S, but the 1+2 markers have a different lexical distribution than those of other persons.

Name: imperative
Comment: Only Sp verbs take second person prefixes (src:wayanatavares2005[226]).

Name: immediate past
Comment: Conservative Set I
